text: we need to do more to stop people
traveling to stop those who do go from
returning Isis now boast militants from
74 countries around the world among its
many thousands of recruits my highest
priority is the security of the American
people how governments are dealing with
their citizens turn jihadis and taking
steps to keep them from coming home now
on the New York Times minute much of
Isis's recent success can be attributed
to its unrivaled international
recruitment drive foreign-born fighters
provide manpower as well as immense
propaganda value we have not yet
detected specific plotting against our
homeland but the fear is that some Isis
fighters may return home and commit acts
of terror counterterrorism experts say
that has been rare in the past but
nonetheless world leaders are changing
laws to limit any possible returns the
ambition to create an extremist perfect
in the heart of Iraq and Syria is a
threat to security Russia has made
joining Isis a criminal offense Saudi
Arabia has done the same meanwhile the
United Kingdom is weighing how to revoke
a Britain citizenship altogether and
later this month at the UN the United
States will propose a binding resolution
to compel member states to help prevent
and suppress the flow of jihadis
but recent history offers an example of
the challenges of protecting against
returning jihadis Monier Mohammed Abu
Saleh was a Florida man who joined the
new sewer front and Isis rival he
traveled to Syria for extremist training
without being noticed by US authorities
he then was able to buy a return ticket
to the u.s. eventually he went back to
Syria and killed himself in a suicide
bombing there as the UN debates the
issue and more countries institute
measures governments will have to
balance their security concerns with the
desire not to alienate their own Muslim
citizens for example if France cracks
down it could have a ricochet effect and
create even more jihadis
